description: Wholesale massacre of all Roman and Italic citizens in Asia Minor, starting the Mithridatic Wars.
name: Asiatic Vespers

description: Gaius Suetonius Paulinus ordered the Roman army to destroy the Celtic Druid stronghold on Anglesey in Britain, sacking Druidic colleges and sacred groves. The massacre helped impose Roman religion on Britain and sent Druidism into a decline from which it never recovered.[5][6]
name: Menai massacre

description: Emperor Theodosius I of Rome ordered the executions after the citizens of Thessaloniki murdered a top-level military commander during a violent protest against the arrest of a popular charioteer.[8][9]
name: Massacre of Thessaloniki

description: Muhammad ordered his followers to attack the Banu Qurayza because according to Muslim tradition he had been ordered to do so by the angel Gabriel.[11][12][13][14][15][16] Muhammad had a treaty with the tribe which was betrayed. 600–900 members of the Banu Qurayza (all males old enough to have pubic hair, all of whom were non-combatants) were beheaded, while the women and children of the tribe were sold into slavery (Tabari, Ibn Ishaq).[14][15][17] Al Waqidi influence is in Ibn Ishaqs biography. Stillman and Watt deny the authenticity of al-Waqidi.[18] Al-Waqidi has been frequently criticized by Muslim Ulama, who claim that he is unreliable.[19][20] A reliable source says all the warriors were killed based on Sa'd ibn Mu'adh judgement whom was appointed by Banu Qurzaya for arbitration.[21][22][23] 2 Muslims were killed[14]
location: Fortress of Banu Qurayza, Saudi Arabia
name: Massacre of Banu Qurayza

description: Charlemagne ordered the massacre of 4,500 imprisoned rebel pagan Saxons in response to losing two envoys, four counts, and twenty nobles in battle with the Saxons during his campaign to conquer and Christianize the Saxons during the Saxon Wars.[25]
name: Massacre of Verden

description: King Æthelred II "the Unready" of England ordered all Danes living in England killed. The Danes were accused of aiding Viking raiders. The King of Denmark, Sweyn Forkbeard, invaded England and deposed King Ethelred in 1013.[27][28][29]
name: St. Brice's Day massacre

description: Apparently angered by a rumour that Jewish vizier Joseph ibn Naghrela intended to assassinate the king and take the throne for himself, a Muslim mob killed him and hung his body on a cross. The mob went on to kill the Jewish population of the city.[31][32][33][34]
name: Massacre of the Jews of Granada

description: Wholesale massacre of all Latin (Western European) inhabitants of Constantinople by a mob.
name: Massacre of the Latins

description: First major military action of the Albigensian Crusade
name: Massacre at Béziers

description: Revolt against king Charles I, starting the War of the Sicilian Vespers
name: Massacre of the French in Sicily

description: Prehistoric massacre of Central Plains villagers in what is now South Dakota, involving scalping and dismemberment of the victims.[39][40]
location: Crow Creek Site, Great Plains, North America
name: Crow Creek massacre

description: Days after his coronation in Stockholm, King Christian II of Denmark – trying to maintain the Kalmar Union, a personal union between Sweden, Norway and Denmark, and thus keep up his claims to the Swedish throne – liquidated nobles and bishops who earlier had opposed him, or who might stir up fresh opposition.[43][44][45]
name: Stockholm massacre

description: The Battle of Cajamarca was the unexpected ambush and seizure of the Inca ruler Atahualpa by a small Spanish force led by Francisco Pizarro, on November 16, 1532. The Spanish killed thousands of Atahualpa's counsellors, commanders and unarmed attendants in the great plaza of Cajamarca, and caused his armed host outside the town to flee. The capture of Atahualpa marked the opening stage of the conquest of the pre-Columbian Inca civilization of Peru.
name: Cajamarca massacre

description: The murder of Huguenot worshipers and citizens in an armed action by troops of Francis, Duke of Guise.
name: Massacre of Vassy

description: Ottoman forces capturing Cyprus killed mostly Greek and Armenian Christian inhabitants.
name: Cyprus massacre

description: The French King's soldiers and subjects slaughtered Huguenots; it was the first massacre to be labeled by that word in the English language.[51][52][53]
name: Massacre of St. Bartholomew's Day

description: English troops commanded by Grey de Wilton massacre Papal invasion forces at Dun an Oir in West Kerry[55]
name: Massacre of Smerwick

description: Fearing an uprising by the large Chinese community in the Philippines, the Spanish colonists carried out a preemptive massacre, largely in the Manila area, in October 1603.
location: Manila, Captaincy General of the Philippines
name: Chinese massacre of 1603

description: The Powhatans killed 347 settlers, almost one-third of the English population of the Virginia colony.
name: Jamestown massacre

description: English settlers under Captain John Mason and Narragansett and Mohegan allies set fire to a fortified Pequot village near the Mystic River.
name: Fort Mystic massacre

description: The Spanish and their Filipino allies carried out a large-scale massacre, in which 17,000 to 22,000 Chinese rebels died.
location: Luzon, Captaincy General of the Philippines
name: "Chinese massacre of 1639" (1961)[60]

description: The Ulster Massacres were a series of massacres and resulting deaths amongst the ~40,000 Protestant settlers which took place in 1641 during the Irish Rebellion.[61][62][63]
name: Ulster massacres

description: The Portadown massacre took place in November 1641 at what is now Portadown, County Armagh. Up to 100 mostly English Protestants were killed in the River Bann by a group of armed Irishmen. This was the biggest massacre of Protestant colonists during the 1641–42 uprising.[64]
name: Portadown massacre

description: Royalist forces killed many of the town's defenders and citizens.[65][66][67]
name: Bolton massacre

description: Qing troops killed residents of Yangzhou as punishment for resistance[68][69]
name: Yangzhou massacre

description: There is no reliable figure, but estimated 1 million out of 3 million Sichuanese died mainly due to the massacre by army of Zhang Xianzhong.[71]
name: Sichuan massacre

description: The Clan Campbell after receiving requested hospitality according to custom, slaughtered their Lamont Clan hosts in their beds and threw their bodies down the well to poison the water should they have missed anyone.
name: Dunoon massacre

description: Government soldiers, mainly from Clan Campbell, killed members of the Clan MacDonald of Glencoe.[73]
name: Massacre of Glencoe

description: A group of Indians attacked settlers on Penn's Creek.
name: Penn's Creek massacre

description: British troops fired at a mob that was protesting at the imprisonment of John Wilkes, whose crime was criticizing King George III.
name: Massacre of St George's Fields

description: British troops fired at a mob of colonists. This helped spark the American Revolution even though an all-colonist jury found the soldiers innocent.[77][78]
name: Massacre in Boston

description: Chipewyan warriors attacked an Inuit camp, killing men, women and children.[80][81][82]
name: Bloody Falls massacre

description: British infantry troops attacked sleeping Continental Light Dragoons using bayonets.[83]
name: Baylor Massacre

description: British loyalists bayonetted Continental Light Dragoons as they slept.
name: Little Egg Harbor massacre

description: Loyalist troops under the command of British Colonel Banastre Tarleton slashed and bayoneted fallen American troops during the late stages of the Battle of Waxhaws. Conflicting contemporary accounts claim violation of an American white flag by one or the other of the sides involved.[85]
name: Waxhaw massacre

description: A group of loyalists and Indians during the American Revolutionary War led by Roland Montour attacked a group of American soldiers.
name: Sugarloaf massacre

description: Patriot militia leader Colonel Henry Lee deceived Loyalist militia under Dr. John Pyle into thinking he was British commander Banastre Tarleton sent to meet them. Lee's men then opened fire, surprising and scattering Pyle's force.
name: Pyle's Massacre

description: Pennsylvania militia men attacked a Moravian mission and killed 96 peaceful Christian American Indians there in retaliation for unrelated deaths of several white Pennsylvanians.[87][88]
name: Gnadenhutten massacre

description: Popular courts in the French Revolution sentenced prisoners to death, including around 240 priests.[91]
name: September Massacres

description: Inhabitants of the Warsaw district Praga were massacred by pillaging Russian troops following the Battle of Praga.
name: Massacre of Praga

description: Massacre of French people in Haiti.
name: 1804 Haiti massacre

description: Whangaroa Māori killed and ate 66 crew and passengers on board the Boyd.[92]
name: Boyd massacre

description: British troops killed 22 unarmed native civilians who were hiding in a cave.[93][94]
name: Madulla

description: The 1818 Uva–Wellassa uprising also known as the Great Rebellion resulted in multiple atrocities against the local Sri Lankans by the British imperialists, including razing and annihilation of villages. The entire Uva region male population above the age of 18 years were killed in revenge for resistance against the British imperialist occupation.[95][96]
name: Uva–Wellassa massacre

description: cavalry charged a meeting of 60,000–80,000 people campaigning for reform of parliamentary representation.[92]
name: Peterloo Massacre

description: Hundreds of Greeks were massacred by the Ottomans, including the Greek patriarch, bishops and officials.
name: Constantinople Massacre of 1821

description: The whole Turkish population of Navarino, which was around 3000, were killed by Greeks.[97]
name: Navarino massacre

description: Tens of thousands of Greeks on the island of Chios were slaughtered by Ottoman troops in 1822.
name: Chios massacre

description: Around 400 Texians killed by Santa Anna's Mexican Army Presidio la Bahia Goliad Palm Sunday March 27, 1836.
name: Goliad massacre

description: Aboriginal Australians killed by a force of colonial mounted police.[99]
name: Waterloo Creek massacre

description: A mainly white posse (one of whom was a black African) killed Aboriginal Australians. The perpetrators were convicted and sentenced to death.[100]
name: Myall Creek massacre

description: In the largest attack by Native Americans on white settlers in Texas, a disaffected band of Cherokee, Caddo, Coushatta, and perhaps other ethnicities formed a war party and killed 18 members of the extended Killough family, who had settled in the area after the Senate of the Republic of Texas nullified the (land) treaty which President Sam Houston had negotiated with the Cherokee.
name: Killough massacre

description: About 240 Livingston County Missouri Regulators militiamen and volunteers killed 18 Mormons and one non-Mormon friend.[103][104]
name: Haun's Mill massacre

description: A series of massacres spanning several years: 1840 – Nuntin, 1840 – Boney Point, 1841 – Butchers Creek – 30–35, 1841 – Maffra, 1842 – Skull Creek, 1842 – Bruthen Creek – "hundreds killed", 1843 – Warrigal Creek – between 60 and 180 shot, 1844 – Maffra, 1846 – South Gippsland – 14 killed, 1846 – Snowy River – 8 killed, 1846–47 – Central Gippsland – 50 or more shot, 1850 – East Gippsland – 15–20 killed, 1850 – Murrindal – 16 poisoned, 1850 – Brodribb River – 15–20 killed.[106] See also Angus McMillan.
name: Gippsland massacres

description: Afghan tribes massacred Elphinstone's British army including some 12,000 civilians.[107][108][109]
name: Massacre of Elphinstone's army

description: Mexican rebels fight American rebels at Caborca, Sonora. Out of less than ninety Americans, about thirty were killed in battle and the rest were executed by the Mexicans.
name: Crabb massacre

description: Mormon militia, some dressed as Indians, and Paiute tribesmen killed and plundered unarmed members of the Baker-Fancher emigrant wagon train.[112]
name: Mountain Meadows massacre

description: Thirteen boys and men, accused of being Union sympathizers and spies, were summarily executed by members of the 64th North Carolina Regiment of the Confederate Army.[113]
location: Madison County, North Carolina, United States
name: Shelton Laurel massacre

description: 3rd Regiment California Volunteer Infantry destroyed a village of Shoshone in southeastern Idaho.[115]
location: Washington Territory near present day Preston, Idaho United States
name: Bear River massacre

description: Pro-Confederate bushwhackers attacked the town of Lawrence, Kansas during the American Civil War in retaliation for the Union attack on Osceola, Missouri.[118][119]
name: Lawrence massacre

description: After their surrender following the Battle of Fort Pillow, most of the Union garrison – consisting primarily of Black troops – as well as civilians, including women and children, were massacred by Confederate forces under the command of General Nathan Bedford Forrest.[121][122][123][124]
name: Fort Pillow massacre

description: Colorado Territory 90-day militia destroyed a peaceful village of Cheyenne and Arapaho on the eastern plains.[126][127]
name: Sand Creek massacre

description: Lt. Col. G.A.Custer's 7th cavalry attacked a village of sleeping Cheyenne led by Black Kettle. Custer reported 103 – later revised to 140 – warriors, "some" women and "few" children killed, and 53 women and children taken hostage. Other casualty estimates by cavalry members, scouts and Indians vary widely, with the number of men killed ranging as low as 11 and the numbers of women and children ranging as high as 75. Before returning to their base, the cavalry killed several hundred Indian ponies and burned the village.[129][130][131][132][133][134][135][136][137][138][139]
name: Washita Massacre

description: A mob of over 500 men entered Chinatown in Los Angeles, rioted, ransacked, then tortured and killed 18 Chinese-Americans, making this among the largest mass lynchings in American history.[141]
name: Chinese massacre of 1871

description: Ottoman army irregulars killed Bulgarian civilians barricaded in Batak's church.[145]
name: Batak massacre

description: Cree warriors, dissatisfied with the lack of support from the Canadian Government for Treaty Indians, and exacerbated by food shortages resulting from the near-extinction of bison, killed nine white settlers, including Indian agent Thomas Quinn.[146][147]
name: Frog Lake Massacre

description: Rioting white immigrant miners killed 28 Chinese miners, wounded 15, and 75 Chinese homes burned.[148][149][150]
name: Rock Springs massacre

description: The U.S. 7th Cavalry intercepted a band of Lakota people on their way to the Pine Ridge Reservation for shelter from the winter; as they were disarming them, a gun was fired, and the soldiers turned their artillery on the Lakota, killing men women and children.[152][153]
location: Wounded Knee, South Dakota, United States
name: Wounded Knee Massacre

description: Sultan Abdul Hamid II ordered Ottoman forces to kill Armenians across the empire.[154][155][156]
name: Hamidian massacres

description: Unarmed striking miners were shot in the back: many were wounded and 19 were killed.
name: Lattimer massacre

description: Mexican Army troops attack Yaqui hostiles west of Guaymas, Sonora, Mexico.
name: Mazocoba massacre

description: During the Second Boer War, Boer forces under Manie Maritz massacred 35 Khoikhoi for being British sympathisers.
name: Leliefontein massacre

description: A U.S. Army force of 540 soldiers under the command of Major General Leonard Wood, accompanied by a naval detachment and with a detachment of native constabulary, armed with artillery and small firearms, attacked a Muslim village hidden in the crater of a dormant volcano.[160]
name: Moro Crater massacre

description: A massacre of striking workers, mostly saltpeter (nitrate) miners, along with wives and children, committed by the Chilean Army in Iquique, Chile. It occurred during the peak of the nitrate mining era, which coincided with the Parliamentary Period in Chilean political history (1891–1925). With the massacre and an ensuing reign of terror, not only was the strike broken, but the workers' movement was thrown into limbo for over a decade.[citation needed]
name: Santa María School massacre

description: In April 1909, a religious-ethnic clash in the city of Adana, amidst governmental upheaval, resulted in a series of anti-Armenian pogroms throughout the district, resulting in an estimated 15,000 to 30,000 deaths.[161][162][163][164][165]
name: Adana massacre

description: Twenty people, 11 of them children, died during an attack by the Colorado National Guard on a tent colony of 1,200 striking coal miners and their families at Ludlow, Colorado. The event led to wider conflict quelled only by Federal troops sent in by U.S. President Woodrow Wilson.[166][167][168]
name: Ludlow massacre

description: At least 360 mostly Russian military personnel and civilians were killed after the Finnish Civil War Battle of Vyborg by the Finnish Whites. The victims include a large number of other nationalities which the Whites presumed as Russians. The killed were not affiliated with the Reds, but most were even White supporters. Also 450–1,200 captured Finnish Red Guard fighters were executed.[169]
name: Vyborg massacre

description: 90 British Indian Army soldiers, led by Brigadier Reginald Dyer, opened fire on an unarmed gathering of men, women and children. The firing lasted for 10 to 15 minutes, until they ran out of ammunition.[171][172]
name: Jallianwala Bagh massacre

description: British Auxiliary police and Black and Tans fired at Gaelic football spectators at Croke Park.[173][174]
name: Croke Park massacre

description: Several days of violence by white mobs, ranging in size up to 400 people, resulted in the deaths of six blacks and two whites and the destruction of the town of Rosewood, which was abandoned after the incident.[175]
name: Rosewood massacre

description: A group of strikers in Canton, China, in support of a workers' strike in Hong Kong, were fired upon by British troops, who claimed to have been provoked by gunfire. Over 200 casualties resulted.
name: Shaji massacre

description: In a fight between Colorado state police and a striking coal miners, the police used firearms, killing six and wounding dozens. The miners claimed that machine guns were fired at them, which was denied by the state police.
name: Columbine Mine massacre

description: 37 children and a 30-year-old teacher at Bathtown elementary school were killed by a major explosion set off by school board treasurer Andrew Kehoe. About a half hour after the explosion, Kehoe then detonated dynamite in his truck, killing himself and five others, including a fourth grader and four adults. Also, some hours before the event, Kehoe killed his wife at their Bath Township home. This event was the deadliest mass murder in a school in United States history.
name: Bath School massacre

description: The last known officially sanctioned massacre of indigenous Australians which took place in the vicinity of Coniston cattle station in Northern Territory, Australia in revenge for the death of a dingo hunter named Frederick Brooks.
name: Coniston massacre

description: The Banana massacre was a massacre of workers for the United Fruit Company that occurred on December 6, 1928 in the town of Ciénaga near Santa Marta, Colombia. An unknown number of workers died after the Conservative government of Miguel Abadía decided to send the Colombian army to end a month-long strike organized by the workers' union in order to secure better working conditions. The government of the United States of America had threatened to invade with the U.S. Marine Corps if the Colombian government did not act to protect United Fruit's interests.
name: Banana massacre

description: Al Capone's gang shot rival gang members and their associates.[180]
name: Saint Valentine's Day massacre

description: Arabs kill 69 Jews after being incited by religious leaders. Survivors were relocated to Jerusalem, "leaving Hebron barren of Jews for the first time in hundreds of years."[181]
name: 1929 Hebron massacre

description: Arabs killed 18 Jews, wounded around 40, and some 200 houses were burned and looted.[183]
name: 1929 Safed massacre

description: Soldiers of the British Raj fired on unarmed non-violent protestors of the Khudai Khidmatgar with machine guns during the Indian independence movement[184][185]
name: Qissa Khwani bazaar massacre

description: Turkish troops massacred Kurdish residents during the Ararat rebellion.
name: Zilan massacre

description: Iraqi Army killed 3,000 Assyrian men, women and children.[188] The massacre, amongst other things, included rape, cars running over children and bayoneting children and pregnant women.[188]
name: Simele massacre

description: The Insular Police fired on unarmed Nationalist demonstrators peacefully marching to commemorate the ending of slavery in Puerto Rico.[189] It was the biggest massacre in Puerto Rican history.[190]
name: Ponce massacre

description: The Dominican military used machetes to brutally slash people to death and decapitate thousands of black Haitians; they also took people to the port of Montecristi, where thousands of Haitians were thrown into the ocean to drown with their hands and feet bound. Their executioners often inflicted wounds on their bodies before throwing them overboard in order to attract sharks. Survivors who managed to cross the border and return to Haiti told stories of family members being hacked with machetes and strangled by the soldiers, and children dashed against rocks and tree trunks.[192]
name: Parsley massacre

description: Turkish troops massacred Alevi residents during the Dersim Rebellion.
name: Dersim massacre

description: The Imperial Japanese Army pillaged and burned Nanking while, at the same time, murdering, enslaving, raping, and torturing prisoners-of-war and civilians.[198]
name: Nanking Massacre

description: Soviet NKVD executed Polish intelligentsia, POWs and reserve officers.[202][203]
name: Katyn massacre

description: Soldiers of the 14th Company, S.S. Division Totenkopf, under the command of Hauptsturmführer Fritz Knöchlein shot prisoners-of-war during the Battle of France.[204]
location_link: Le Paradis village, commune of Lestrem, Northern France
name: Le Paradis massacre

description: The Soviet NKVD executed thousands of political prisoners in the initial stages of Operation Barbarossa.[205][206]
name: NKVD prisoner massacres

description: Nazi Einsatzgruppen killed the Jewish population of Kiev.[207][208][209][210][211]
name: Babi Yar massacre

description: Nazi soldiers massacred Serb and Roma hostages in retaliation for attacks on the occupying forces.
name: Kragujevac massacre

description: Romanian and German troops, supported by local authorities, massacred Jews in Odessa and the surrounding towns in Transnistria after a bomb detonated in the Romanian HQ.[212]
name: Odessa massacre

description: The first systematic mass killings of German Jews during the Holocaust.
name: Ninth Fort massacres of November 1941

description: The Japanese killed surrendered Australian soldiers.[213][214]
name: Laha massacre

description: Nazis killed 192 men, and sent the women and children to Nazi concentration camps where many died.[215][216][217]
name: Lidice massacre

description: Wehrmacht troops executed 5,155 POWs from the Italian 33 Infantry Division Acqui after the latter refused to hand over their weapons and resisted. A further 3,000 Italian POWs drowned at sea on transports that sank after hitting mines.
name: Massacre of the Acqui Division

description: Japanese forces under Rear Admiral Shigematsu Sakaibara massacred the remaining 98 U.S. civilians in fear of the anticipation U.S. invasion of Wake Island two days after a U.S. air raid on the island.[219][220]
name: Wake Island massacre

description: The extermination of the male population and the subsequent total destruction of the town of Kalavryta, in Greece, by German occupying forces during World War II on 13 December 1943. It is the most serious case of war crimes committed during the Axis occupation of Greece during World War II.
name: Massacre of Kalavryta

description: The Khaibakh massacre refers to a report of mass execution of the ethnically Chechen population of the aul of Khaibakh, in the mountainous part of Chechnya, by Soviet forces under NKVD Colonel Mikhail Gveshiani.
name: Khaibakh massacre

description: Mass killing carried out by German occupation troops as a reprisal for a partisan attack conducted on the previous day in central Rome against the SS Police Regiment Bozen.
name: Ardeatine massacre

description: The Waffen-SS killed 86 men after a bomb attack in the Gare d'Ascq.
name: Ascq massacre

description: The Waffen-SS killed 642 men, women and children without giving any specific reasons for their actions.[221][222][223][224][225][226]
name: Oradour-sur-Glane massacre

description: Nazi war crime perpetrated by members of the Waffen-SS in the village of Distomo, Greece, during the Axis occupation of Greece during World War II.
name: Distomo massacre

description: Special groups of SS and German soldiers of the Wehrmacht went from house to house in Warsaw district Wola, rounding-up and shooting all inhabitants.
name: Wola massacre

description: Retreating SS-men of the II Battalion of SS-Panzergrenadier–Regiment 35 of 16th SS Panzergrenadier Division Reichsführer-SS, rounded up 560 villagers and refugees — mostly women, children and older men — shot them and then burned their bodies.
name: Sant'Anna di Stazzema massacre

description: Mass murders of citizens of Warsaw district Ochota in August 1944, committed by Waffen-SS.
name: Ochota massacre

description: The townspeople of Rüsselsheim killed six American POWs who were walking through the bombed-out town while escorted by two German guards.
name: Rüsselsheim massacre

description: The SS killed Italian civilians in reprisal for support given to the resistance movement.[227][228]
name: Marzabotto massacre

description: Nazi Waffen-SS soldiers shot American POWs (43 escaped).[229][230]
name: Malmedy massacre

description: German prisoners of war were shot by American soldiers in an unauthorized retaliation for the Malmedy Massacre.
name: Chenogne massacre

description: Japanese occupying forces massacred an estimated 100,000 Filipino civilians during the Battle of Manila.
name: Manila massacre

description: Massacre of concentration camp inmates that took place in Celle at the end of the Second World War.
name: Celle massacre

description: Fleeing Croatian soldiers, members of the Chetnik movement and Slovene Home Guard associated with the fascist Ustaše Regime of Croatia were apprehended by Yugoslav Partisans at the Austrian border. Among those killed were an unknown number of civilians.
name: Bleiburg massacre

description: Muslim villages were bombed by French aircraft and the cruiser Duguay-Trouin standing off the coast, in the Gulf of Bougie, shelled Kerrata. Pied noir vigilantes lynched prisoners taken from local gaols or randomly shot Muslims[233][234][235]
name: Sétif massacre

description:
The Ústí massacre (Czech: Ústecký masakr, German: Massaker von Aussig) was a lynching of ethnic Germans in Ústí nad Labem (German: Aussig an der Elbe), a largely ethnic German city in northern Bohemia ("Sudetenland") shortly after the end of the World War II, on July 31, 1945.
[236][237][238]
location: Ústí nad Labem, today Czech republic
name: Ústí massacre

description: It was an anti-government uprising in Taiwan, and was violently suppressed by the Kuomintang government.
name: February 28 Incident

description: 11 people were killed and 27 wounded during May Day celebrations in Sicily on May 1, 1947, in the municipality of Piana degli Albanesi, by the bandit and separatist leader Salvatore Giuliano and his band.
name: Portella della Ginestra massacre

description: Almost all men in the Indonesian village of Rawagede (modern-day Balongsari) were killed in retaliation by the KNIL, having refused to disclose the location of a wanted Indonesian independence fighter, Lukas Kustaryo. Most estimates place the number at 431.
name: Rawagede massacre

description: Irgun throws a bomb on a group of 100 Palestinian refinery workers, killing 6 and wounding 42. Palestinian workers then attack Jewish refinery workers in retaliation, resulting in 39 deaths and 49 injuries,[239]
name: Haifa Oil Refinery massacre

description: Haganah attacks residents of Palestinian Balad al-Shaykh village, killing 21 while residents were asleep.
name: Balad al-Shaykh massacre

description: Brutal suppression of an uprising. Many Communist sympathizer civilians were killed by South Korean troops whilst putting down the rebellion. Between 14,000 and 60,000 people died during the uprising.[241]
name: Jeju massacre

description: The Deir Yassin massacre took place when the Irgun and Lehi militant groups attacked the Palestinian Arab village of Deir Yassin near Jerusalem, population of 750. Fatalities were estimated between 107–254 villagers, including civilian men, women, and children.[242]
name: Deir Yassin massacre

description: Convoy, escorted by Haganah militia, bringing medical and fortification supplies and personnel to Hadassah Hospital on Mount Scopus was ambushed by Arab forces. 78 Jews, mainly doctors and nurses, were killed in the ambush.[243]
name: Hadassah medical convoy massacre

description: Arab armed forces attacked a Jewish kibbutz the day before the Declaration of Independence of the state of Israel[244][245]
name: Kfar Etzion massacre

description: The village was attacked by the Givati Brigade on May 13–14, 1948 during Operation Barak. More recently, research conducted by Birzeit University suggests that between 60–70 Palestinian residents were killed or massacred during the attack.[246]
name: Abu Shusha massacre

description: Some 200 unarmed Palestinian Tantura villagers, mostly young men, were shot dead after the village had surrendered following the on0,000,079of Haganah troops.[247]
name: Tantura massacre

description: Over 150 Palestinian civilians had taken shelter in the Dahamsh Mosque during the Israeli conquest of Lydda (today's Lod) when an Israeli soldier dug a hole in the wall of the mosque and shot an anti-tank shell through it. All were crushed against the walls by the pressure from the blast and killed.[248] Also killed were 20 more after cleaning up the scene of the massacre. More civilians were killed as Israeli soldiers of the 89th Brigade, led by Moshe Dayan, throw grenades inside Palestinian houses, and those who fled to the streets were shot at by Israeli forces. Almost the entire population of Lydda, about 50,000 civilians at the time, which included many refugees, were then expelled and hundreds of men, women and children died due to dehydration, exhaustion and disease during a "death march" to the Arab front lines.[249]
name: Lydda massacre

description: The killing of civilians by the Israeli army (IDF) that took place in the Palestinian Arab town of al-Dawayima on during the 1948 Arab–Israeli War.[250][251]
name: Al-Dawayima massacre

description: Israeli army kills 14 Palestinian Christians from the Eilaboun village, in north Israel, and expels the rest of the residents to Lebanon. Part of the community returns some months thereafter, due to pressure from the United Nations and the Vatican.
name: Eilabun massacre

description: Hula is a Lebanese Shi'a Muslim village near the Lebanese Litani River. It was captured by the Carmeli Brigade of the Israel Defense Forces without any resistance. 35–58 captured men were reportedly shot down in a house which was later blown up on top of them. Two officers were responsible for the massacre; one served a one-year prison sentence and later received presidential amnesty. Shmuel Lahis was later to become Director General of the Jewish Agency.[252][253]
name: Hula massacre

description: 94 Palestinian villagers are packed inside an abode, which was then blown up over their heads by the Israeli Seventh Brigade.[254]
name: Saliha massacre

description: Villagers were purportedly shot by British troops before the village was burnt.[255][256][257]
name: Batang Kali massacre

description: Communist sympathizer civilians were killed by South Korean troops.
name: Mungyeong massacre

description: During the Korean War, communist sympathizer civilians or prisoners were killed by South Korean troops. Some scholars insist that the number of victims is between 100,000 and 200,000,[261] but the confirmed number by Truth and Reconciliation Commission(2005) is 4,934.
name: Bodo League massacre

description: During the Korean War, medical personnels, inpatients and wounded soldiers were killed by North Korean troops. There were 900 victims.[262]
name: Seoul National University Hospital massacre

description: Early in the Korean War, South Korean refugees trying to cross U.S. lines at No Gun Ri were killed by U.S. troops fearing North Korean infiltrators. In 2005, the South Korean government certified the names of 150 dead, 13 missing and 55 wounded, some of whom died of wounds, and said reports on many more victims were not filed.[263] Survivors estimated 400 dead.[264]
name: No Gun Ri massacre

description: During the Korean War, American POWs were massacred by North Korean Army on August 14, 1950.[265]
name: Hill 303 massacre

description: During the Korean War, South Korean citizens were massacred by South Korean police between October 1950 and early 1951.[267][268]
name: Namyangju massacre

description: During the Korean War, South Korean civilians were massacred by South Korean police between October 9 to October 31, 1950.[269]
name: Goyang Geumjeong Cave massacre

description: The North Korean government claims that North Korean citizens were massacred by United States forces between October 17 to December 7, 1950.[266] This is widely disputed.
name: Sinchon Massacre

description: During the Korean War, Communist collaborator civilians were massacred by South Korean forces, South Korean Police forces and pro-South Korea forces militia.
name: Ganghwa massacre

description: During the Korean War, Communist sympathizer civilians were massacred by South Korean Army on February 7, 1951.[272]
name: Sancheong and Hamyang massacre

description: During the Korean War, Communist sympathizer civilians were massacred by South Korean Army between February 9 and February 11, 1951.[273]
name: Geochang massacre

description: About 150 Kikuyu were killed by fellow tribesmen.[274][275]
name: Lari massacre

description: Also known as the Qibya incident, occurred during "Operation Shoshana" when Israeli troops under Ariel Sharon attacked the village of Qibya in the West Bank. At least sixty-nine Palestinian villagers were killed, two-thirds of them women and children.
name: Qibya massacre

description: Israeli Border Police shoot Israeli Arab farmers returning to their village from work, unaware of a curfew imposed on it. The police command ordered that civilians caught disobeying the curfew be shot. Over half the casualties were women and children.
name: Kafr Qasim massacre

description: South African police shot down black protesters.[277]
name: Sharpeville massacre

description: Makonde nationalists organized a demonstration in front of the Mueda District headquarters on the Mueda town square demanding independence from Portugal, apparently the district administrator had invited them to present their grievances.[278] The administrator ordered the leaders arrested, and the crowd protested.[279] The Portuguese administrator ordered his pre-assembled troops to fire on the crowd,[280] and then many more were thrown to their death into a ravine.[281] The number of dead is in dispute.[282] However, resentment generated by these events led ultimately to independentist guerrilla FRELIMO gaining needed momentum in the outset of the Mozambican War of Independence.[279][280]
name: Mueda massacre

description: French police, commanded by Maurice Papon, crushed a pacific demonstration of Algerians independentists.
name: Paris massacre of 1961

description: The MVD open fire on a crowd of protesters demonstrating against inflation.[285]
name: Novocherkassk massacre

description: Massacre of civilians including Europeans by an angry mob at the end of the Algerian War (1954–62).
name: Oran massacre of 1962

description: The Dominican military dropped napalm on the Liboristas from airplanes – burning six hundred people to death.
name: Liborista massacre

description: University of Texas at Austin was the site of a massacre by Charles Whitman, who killed his mother and wife at their homes before killing 15 and wounding 32 others at the University atop the university tower before the police killed him.
name: University of Texas massacre

description: South Korean soldiers purportedly killed 68 South Vietnamese villagers.[287]
location: Binh Tai village in Phước Bình District of Sông Bé Province, South Vietnam
name: Binh Tai Massacre

description: South Korean soldiers purportedly killed South Vietnamese villagers.[288]
location: Binh Hoa village in Quảng Ngãi Province, South Vietnam
name: Bình Hòa massacre

description: During the 1968 Tet Offensive in the Vietnam War, unarmed South Vietnamese civilians were massacred by North Vietnamese Army and Vietcong. Numerous mass graves were discovered in and around Huế after the Offensive. Victims included women, men, children, and infants.[291] Estimated death toll was between 2,800 - 6,000 civilians and POWs.[292] The Republic of Vietnam released a list of 4,062 victims identified as having been either murdered or abducted.[293][294] Victims were found bound, tortured, and often buried alive.[295][296][297] Many victims were also clubbed to death.[298]
name: Huế massacre

description: The Jabidah massacre was the killing of Moro soldiers by members of the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) on March 18, 1968.[299][300][301]
name: Jabidah massacre

description: South Korean soldiers killed unarmed South Vietnamese villagers.
location:
Phong Nhi and Phong Nhat hamlets,
Dien Ban District of Quảng Nam Province, South Vietnam
name: Phong Nhi and Phong Nhat massacre

description: South Korean soldiers purportedly killed unarmed South Vietnamese villagers.
location: Hà My village, Quảng Nam Province, South Vietnam
name: Hà My massacre

description: U.S. soldiers murdered, tortured and assaulted 347–504 unarmed South Vietnamese villagers suspected of aiding the Vietcong, ranging in ages from 1–81 years, mostly women and children.[304][305]
location:
Mỹ Lai and Mỹ Khê hamlets,
Sơn Mỹ, Quảng Ngãi, South Vietnam
name: My Lai Massacre

description: Government troops massacred between 25 (officially) and 250 (according to human rights activists, CIA documents[308] and independent investigations) students 10 days before the 1968 Summer Olympics taking place in Mexico City, and then tried to wash the blood away, along with evidence of the massacre.[307][309]
name: Tlatelolco massacre

description: 29 members of the Ohio National Guard opened fire on unarmed students protesting the expansion of the Vietnam War into Cambodia on the Kent State University college campus, killing 4 and wounding 9, one of whom was permanently paralyzed.[310][311][312]
location: Kent State University, Ohio, United States
name: Kent State massacre

description: Massacre of unarmed Bengali Hindus in Ketnar Bil region of Barisal District by the Pakistan Army.
name: Ketnar Bil massacre

description: Similar to the Tlatelolco Massacre, the Corpus Christi Massacre took place on Thursday, June 10, 1971 when a student march got brutally attacked by a shock group called Los Halcones.
name: Corpus Christi massacre

description: British paratroopers fired on unarmed civil rights protesters, killing 14.[315] The government sponsored Saville Report, released in June 2010, found all those killed were innocent civil rights demonstrators, prompting an apology by UK Prime Minister David Cameron. As of that time, no one had been prosecuted for the killings.[316]
name: Bogside massacre

description: Three members of the Japanese Red Army, on behalf of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, killed 26 people and injured 80 others at Tel Aviv's Lod airport (now Ben Gurion International Airport).[317][318][319][320][321]
name: Lod Airport massacre

description: Members of the Israeli Olympic team were taken hostage and killed by the Palestinian Black September group. A West German police officer was also killed.
name: Munich massacre

description: Members of the right wing of the Peronist party shot and killed at least 13 after Peron's return to Argentina.
name: Ezeiza massacre

description: Soldiers of the Armed Forces of the Philippines looted and burned the southern Philippine town of Jolo, Sulu and killed many of its Muslim Tausug inhabitants while leaving many more homeless after an engagement with the Moro rebels.
name: Jolo massacre

description: Members of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine infiltrate Israel from Lebanon, shoot and kill a Christian Arab woman and a Jewish couple and their 4-year-old son, and then take hostage and kill 22 high school students and three of their adult escorts.[327]
name: Ma'alot massacre

description: EOKA-B gunmen massacred the Turkish Cypriot inhabitants of the villages of Maratha, Santalaris and Aloda.[328][331]
name: Maratha, Santalaris and Aloda massacre

description: Soldiers of the Armed Forces of the Philippines murdered male Muslim Moros aged 11–70 years old in a village surrounding a nearby mosque.
name: Malisbong Massacre

description: Members of the Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF) with backing from the British Army forces killed three members of pop group the Miami Showband in a gun and bomb attack. Two UVF members also died when the bomb exploded prematurely.[333][334][335][336][337]
name: Miami Showband massacre

description: Irish republicans shot ten Protestant workers dead outside the village of Kingsmill in County Armagh, Northern Ireland.[338][339]
name: Kingsmill massacre

description: Lebanese Christian militia overrun the Karantina district in East Beirut and kill up to 1,500 Palestinians and Muslims during the Lebanese Civil War.[340]
name: Karantina massacre

description: Palestinian militia aligned with the Lebanese National Movement kill 150–582 Christian civilians in the village of Damour during the Lebanese Civil War, in retaliation for the Karantina massacre.[341]
name: Damour massacre

description: Lebanese Christian militias enter the Tel al-Zaatar refugee camp and kill up to 3,000 people during the Lebanese Civil War.[342][343]
name: Tel al-Zaatar massacre

description: Palestinian Fatah members based in Lebanon land on a beach north of Tel Aviv, kill an American photographer, and hijack an inter-city bus driving along Israel's Coastal Highway. 35 civilians are killed and 80 wounded.[344][345][346][347]
name: Coastal Road massacre

description: Marichjhapi massacre refers to the forcible eviction of Bangladeshi refugees and their subsequent death by starvation, exhaustion and police firing in the period between January–June, 1979.
name: Marichjhapi massacre

description: An escalated popular uprising in the city of Gwangju, South Korea during which some of the civilian protesters armed themselves by raiding police stations and military depots led to the South Korean army violently ending the protests, causing 165 (maximum estimated) of deaths (including 24 soldiers, 4 policemen).
name: Gwangju massacre

description: The massacre occurred the day after a failed attempt to assassinate Syrian president Hafez el-Assad. Members of the units of the Defence Brigades, under the command of Rifaat El Assad, brother of the president, entered in Tadmor Prison and assassinated about a thousand prisoners in the cells and the dormitories.
name: Tadmor Prison massacre

description: The El Mozote Massacre took place in the village of El Mozote, in Morazán department, El Salvador, on December 11, 1981, when Salvadoran armed forces trained by the United States military killed at least 1,000 civilians in an anti-guerrilla campaign.[349]
name: El Mozote massacre

description: 13 tortured bodies were found at Tula, Hidalgo, Mexico at the time of Arturo Durazo Moreno Administration.
name: Tula massacre

description: The Syrian Army killed an estimated 30,000 people in the city of Hama. Instances of mass execution and torture by the Syrian military were documented during the attacks.[351]
name: Hama massacre

description: Residents of Sabra and Shatila, mostly Palestinian refugees and Lebanese Shia, are killed by the Christian Lebanese Forces militia in the refugee camps, with the help of Israeli forces that encircled the area. The United Nations General Assembly condemned the massacre and declared it to be an act of genocide.[352][353][354]
name: Sabra and Shatila massacre

description: Maoist Shining Path guerrillas massacre 69 men, women and children with axes, machetes and guns in and around the town of Lucanamarca, Peru.[355]
name: Lucanamarca massacre

description: a massacre of ethnic Somalis by Kenyan security forces who first gathered them at the Wagalla Airstrip, Wajir County, Kenya.
name: Wagalla massacre

description: Gunman James Oliver Huberty killed 21 people in a McDonald's restaurant before being fatally shot by a SWAT team sniper.[356][357][358]
name: San Ysidro McDonald's massacre

description: Mobs composed primarily of Indian National Congress workers and local hoodlums chase down and lynch Sikhs in northern India following the assassination of India PM, Indira Gandhi, at the hands of her Sikh guards.
name: 1984 Sikh massacre

description: Dujail was the site of an unsuccessful assassination attempt against then Iraqi president, Saddam Hussein by the Shiite Dawa Party, on July 8, 1982. Saddam Hussein ordered his special security and military forces to arrest all Dawa members and their families, imprisoning 787 men, women and children. In March 1985, 96 of the 148 who had confessed to having taken part in the assassination attempt were executed.[359][360][361][362]
name: Dujail Massacre

description: Tamil Tiger gunmen shoot dead 146 Sinhalese civilians including Buddhist nuns and monks and injure 85 others as they were praying at Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi, a sacred Buddhist shrine in Anuradhapura.[364]
name: Anuradhapura massacre

description: An army massacre of campesinos (including six children) in Accomarca, Ayacucho.[366]
name: Accomarca massacre

description: Republic of China Army executed all the unarmed Vietnamese refugees in a disoriented fishing boat seeking for political asylum at Donggang beach of Lieyu, Kinmen on March 7–8, 1987.[368]
name: Lieyu massacre

description: Tamil Tigers stop a bus carrying Buddhist monks in Arantalawa and massacre all except of one monk. Killed in the massacre are Chief Priest Ven. Hegoda Indrasara and several novice monks (under the age of 18)[369]
name: Aranthalawa Massacre

description: The Hoddle Street massacre was a killing spree which claimed the lives of 7 people and wounded 19 others at Hoddle Street in Clifton Hill in north-eastern Melbourne, Victoria, Australia.[371]
name: Hoddle Street massacre

description: A gunman armed with semi-automatic rifles and a handgun killed 16 people before committing suicide.[373]
name: Hungerford massacre

description: Provisional IRA bombing at the town's cenotaph on Remembrance Sunday.[375]
name: Poppy Day Massacre

description: The Queen Street massacre was a killing spree which claimed the lives of 8 people and wounded 5 others in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia.[371]
name: Queen Street massacre

description: Ulster Defence Association (UDA) member Michael Stone kills three people and injures 60 others in a gun and grenade attack at the funeral of three IRA members being held in Milltown Cemetery, Belfast.[376][377]
name: Milltown massacre

description: The mourning of Hu Yaobang eventually evolved into a large-scale anti-corruption and democratic demonstration, which was ended in a violent suppression by state-controlled army. The actual number of deaths is still unknown. The massacre did not occur within Tiananmen Square, but in the surrounding areas of the square.[380][381]
name: Tiananmen Square massacre

description: Following a failed coup, 12 officers were shot dead by forces loyal to Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega.[382][383][384][385]
name: Albrook massacre

description: Marc Lépine, a misogynist and anti-feminist, shot and killed 14 female students of the École Polytechnique de Montréal and wounded 14 other people before turning his gun on himself. The event led to stricter gun control laws and changes in police tactical response to shootings in Canada.[387][388]
name: École Polytechnique massacre

description: Eastern University massacre is the massacre of 158 minority Sri Lankan Tamil civilians by the Sri Lankan Army in the eastern Batticaloa District, Sri Lanka.[389][390][391]
name: Eastern University massacre

description: Indian paramilitary troops of the Central Reserve Police Force opened fire on Kashmiri protesters.
name: Gawkadal massacre

description: Sathurukondan massacre, also known as the 1990 Batticaloa massacre is the massacre of 184 minority Sri Lankan Tamil civilians by the Sri Lankan Army in the eastern Batticaloa District, Sri Lanka.[392][393][394][395][396]
name: Sathurukondan massacre

description: Lone gunman David Malcolm Gray began shooting indiscriminately at people, killing 13 people before being killed by police himself, allegedly after a dispute with his next door neighbor. It remains New Zealand's deadliest criminal shooting.[397][398][399][400]
name: Aramoana massacre

description: George Jo Hennard drove his pickup truck into a Luby's Cafeteria and shot and killed 22 people, wounded another 20 and then committed suicide by shooting himself.[401][402][403][404][405]
name: Luby's shooting

description: Fifteen people were killed and four injured when Grupo Colina, the anti-communist paramilitary squad, opened fire on a neighborhood barbecue which they had mistaken for a gathering of Maoist Shining Path rebels.[406]
name: Barrios Altos massacre

description: An estimated 270 pro-independence demonstrators were killed in the Santa Cruz Cemetery while conducting a peaceful memorial service during the Indonesian Occupation of East Timor and is part of the East Timorese Genocide.[407]
name: Santa Cruz massacre

description: An estimated 2,000 civilians were massacred in Bor during the Second Sudanese Civil War by Nuer fighters from SPLA-Nasir, led by Riek Machar, and the militant group known as the Nuer White Army.[408]
name: Bor massacre

description: Members of the Serb militias, aided by the Yugoslav People's Army, killed Croat civilians and POWs.[409][410][411][412]
name: Vukovar massacre

description: Armenian armed forces, reportedly with help of the Russian 366th Motor Rifle Regiment, raided the town of Khojaly and massacred its Muslim civilian population. The death toll according to the Government of Azerbaijan was 613 civilians, of whom 106 were women and 83 were children.[414][415][416]
name: Khojaly Massacre

description: 45 African National Congress (ANC) supporters were killed by members of the Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP).
name: Boipatong massacre

description: 9 students and a professor on La Cantuta University were kidnapped and killed by Grupo Colina, an anticommunist paramilitary group.
name: La Cantuta massacre

description: 28 African National Congress (ANC) supporters and one soldier were shot dead by the Ciskei Defence Force during a protest march.
name: Bisho massacre

description: The massacre was triggered by a prisoner revolt within the prison. The police made little if any effort to negotiate with the prisoners before the military police stormed the building, as the prison riot became more difficult for prison guards to control. The resulting casualties were of 111 prisoners killed.
name: Carandiru massacre

description: Seven people were murdered at the Brown's Chicken and Pasta in Palatine[419]
name: Brown's Chicken massacre

description:
Incidents of ethnic cleansing of Georgians in Abkhazia,[421][422][423][424]
[425][426][427][428][429][430][431][432] also known as the "massacres of Georgians in Abkhazia"[433][434] and "genocide of Georgians in Abkhazia"[435] — refers to ethnic cleansing,[436] massacres[437] and forced mass expulsion of thousands of ethnic Georgians.
name: Sukhumi massacre

description: Seventy-six members of the Branch Davidian church died after a 51-day siege in a fire started either accidentally or by church members after a Federal Bureau of Investigation tank attack upon the main building. Earlier, on February 28, 1993, six others died by gunfire after the original Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms raid.[439]
name: Massacre at Waco

description: Garimpeiros (illegal gold miners) killed Yanomami people.
name: Yanomami or Haximu massacre

description: 35 people (mostly Alevi intellectuals) were killed when a mob of Islamic extremists set fire to the hotel where the group had assembled.[442][443][444]
name: Sivas massacre

description: Several PKK members stormed the village and killed 33 civilians after rounding them up. Also over 200 houses, a clinic, a school and a mosque were burned down.[445][446]
name: Başbağlar massacre

description: 11 People were killed during a church service by Azanian People's Liberation Army (APLA) armed with assault rifles and grenades.
name: St James Church massacre

description: Ulster Defence Association (UDA) opened fire in a crowded bar using an AK-47 and automatic pistol. Eight civilians were killed and thirteen wounded.[447][448][449][450][451][452][453][454]
name: Greysteel massacre

description: Israeli settler Baruch Goldstein opens fire with an assault rifle against Palestinian Muslims, killing 29 and wounding 150 at prayer in the Ibrahimi Mosque in Hebron before being subdued and beaten to death by survivors.[458][459]
name: Cave of the Patriarchs massacre

description: During the 1990s, many large-scale massacres of villagers in Algeria were perpetrated by groups attacking villages at night and cutting the throats of the inhabitants. The Armed Islamic Group (GIA) has avowed its responsibility for many of them. The massacres peaked in 1997 (with a smaller peak in 1994). According to a few reports former Algerian army officer, Habib Souaidia testified to his government's involvement in the massacres. The differing accounts are not yet reconciled.[460][462][463][464] The academic consensus is that at least the majority of the massacres were carried out by Islamist radicals, however, the government notably failed to intervene in a number of these massacres.[465]
name: Algerian Village massacres of the 1990s

description: Security guards of the African National Congress (ANC) fired on 20,000 Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) marchers.[466][467][468]
name: Shell House massacre

description: Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF) opened fire in a crowded bar using assault rifles, killing six civilians and wounding five.[469][470][471][472][473][474][475]
name: Loughinisland massacre

description: First suicide attack by Palestinian Islamic Jihad, killing 22 and wounding 69. Carried out by two bombers; the second waited until emergency crews arrived to assist the wounded and dying before detonating his bomb.[477][478][479][480]
name: Beit Lid massacre

description: The Srebrenica massacre involved the genocidal killing, in July 1995, of 8,372 Bosniaks, mainly men and boys, in and around the town of Srebrenica during the Bosnian War.
name: Srebrenica massacre

description: A gunman opened fire in a primary school, killing sixteen children and one teacher before killing himself.[482][483][484]
name: Dunblane massacre

description: The Port Arthur massacre of 28 April 1996 was a killing spree which claimed the lives of 35 people and wounded 21 others mainly at the historic tourist site Port Arthur in south-eastern Tasmania, Australia. It later emerged that the gunman had severe intellectual disability.[485] The massacre remains Australia's deadliest mass killing spree and remains one of the deadliest such incidents worldwide in recent times.[371]
name: Port Arthur massacre

description: Israeli artillery struck the Unifil Headquarters in Qana which was providing shelter to approximately two hundred Lebanese civilians. The Israeli military said the strike was in error and that they were not targeting the UN shelter. An amateur film was released showing that, contrary to Israeli assertions, an Israeli drone was spying on the UN compound just before it was shelling.[488] The UN concluded that the attack was intentional. Amnesty International also concluded, "the IDF intentionally attacked the UN compound.[489][490][491][492][493][494]
name: First Qana massacre

description: After two days of protests during which the protesters had marched shouting "God is great" and "independence for Xinjiang" the demonstrations were crushed by the People's Liberation Army. Official reports put the death toll at 9 while dissident reports estimated the number killed at more than 100.[496][497][498][499][500][501]
name: Ghulja massacre

description: Massacre carried out by Egyptian Islamist militants, in which 64 people (including 59 visiting tourists) were killed using automatic weapons and machetes.[502][503][504]
name: Luxor massacre

description: Massacre carried out by paramilitary forces of 45 people attending a prayer meeting of indigenous townspeople, who were members of the pacifist group Las Abejas ("The Bees"), in the village of Acteal, municipality of Chenalhó, in the Mexican state of Chiapas.[505][506][507]
name: Acteal massacre

description: The Omagh bombing was a car bomb attack carried out by the Real Irish Republican Army, a splinter group of former Provisional Irish Republican Army members opposed to the Good Friday Agreement. Twenty-nine people died and approximately 220 people were injured.The attack was described by the BBC as "Northern Ireland's worst single terrorist atrocity".[509][510][511][512][513][514]
name: Omagh massacre

description: Two teenagers, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold open fire on their classmates on April 20, 1999 at Columbine High School, killing 12 students and a teacher and injuring 21 others before committing suicide in the school's library.
name: Columbine High School Massacre

description: Killing of 11 landless labourers allegedly by activists of Communist Party of India (Marxist), a political party in India, in Suchpur, near Nanoor and under Nanoor police station, in Birbhum district in the Indian state of West Bengal.[517][518][519]
name: Nanoor massacre

description: A Hamas suicide bomber blows himself up outside a nightclub in Tel Aviv, killing at least 21 teenage girls and 4 adults. The youngest victim was 14 years old, and a majority of the teenage girls were of Russian origin.[520]
name: Dolphinarium discotheque massacre

description: An attack carried out in January 2002 by al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades in which a Palestinian gunman hurling grenades killed six and wounded 33 in a Bat Mitzvah celebration, a traditional Jewish celebration held for a 12-year-old girl.[521][522]
name: Bat Mitzvah massacre

description: During the 2002 Gujarat riots, a mob attacked the Gulbarg Society, a lower middle-class Muslim neighbourhood in Chamanpura, Ahmedabad. Most of the houses were burnt, and at least 35 victims including a former Congress, Member of Parliament, Ehsan Jafri, were burnt alive, while 31 others went missing after the incident, later presumed dead, bringing the total of the dead to 69.[523][524][525]
name: Gulbarg Society massacre

description: Killing of 30 guests at the Park Hotel in Netanya, Israel, sitting down to the traditional Passover Seder meal. Another 143 were injured. Hamas claimed responsibility.[526][527][528][529][530]
name: Passover massacre

description: Armed Chechen separatists[531] took more than 1,200 people hostage at a school. 334 civilians were killed, including 186 school children, and hundreds wounded.[532][533][534]
name: Beslan school hostage crisis

description: Brothers Sylvester and Gavin Beukes murder the owners' couple of farm Kareeboomvloer and execute all witnesses, including two children.[535] The motive was revenge for a previous theft charge laid by the farm owner.[536]
name: Kareeboomvloer massacre

description: Uzbek Interior Ministry and National Security Service troops fired into a crowd of protesters.[537][538]
name: Andijan massacre

description: In protest of Ariel Sharon's government evacuation of Gaza colonies, Jewish IDF soldier Eden Natan-Zada travels to Israeli Arab city Shefa-Amr and unloads his gun against residents of a Druze neighborhood.
name: Shafram massacre (2005)[539]

description: US Marines slaughter 24 unarmed Iraqi civilians, among whom numerous children and the elderly. Though the unit's commander, Staff Sgt Frank Wuterich, claimed his forces came under attack just before the rampage, no weapons were found in the area.[540]
name: Haditha massacre

description: 28-year-old Kyle Aaron Huff entered a rave afterparty in the southeast part of Seattle's Capitol Hill neighborhood and opened fire, killing six and wounding two, before committing suicide.[541]
name: Capitol Hill massacre

description: Airstrike by the Israeli Air Forces on three-storey kill 28 civilians, including 16 children. The Israeli military alleged the compound was used by Hezbollah to store weapons but international observers and journalists denied military equipment was found on the rubble of the building from where the bodies of the victims, civilians in their pajamas were taken.[542]
name: Qana airstrike

description: Gunman Seung-Hui Cho, killed 32 people and wounded many others[543] before committing suicide. The massacre one of the deadliest peacetime shooting incidents by a single gunman in United States history, on or off a school campus.[544]
name: Virginia Tech massacre

description: Guinean uniformed security forces opened fire on a political rally trapped in the 28 September Stadium.[545]
name: 28 September massacre

description: Gunman Malik Nadal Hasan, a Major in the U.S. Army, killed 12 soldiers and one civilian, and wounded at least 30 on the base at Ft. Hood. Initial reports indicate Hassan was upset at being deployed to Iraq.[546][547][548][549][550][551]
name: Fort Hood massacre

description: A group of 100 armed men, alleged to include police and private militia led by Andal Ampatuan, Jr., stopped a convoy of five cars transporting Genalyn Tiamzon-Mangudadatu, the wife of Esmael Mangudadatu, who is running for provincial governor in the 2010 Philippine elections. She was en route to the town of Shariff Aguak to file a certificate of candidacy for her husband, accompanied by his sisters, other supporters, and members of the press. The attackers kidnapped and later killed all members of the Mangudadatu group; reports state that women in the group were raped before being killed. Five other people not part of the group, in a car behind the convoy, were also kidnapped and killed.[552][553][554][555][556]
name: Maguindanao massacre

description: In what was believed to be a revenge operation, members of the Murle tribe attacked members of the Nuer tribe, burning down over 3,400 houses and the hospital ran by Médecins Sans Frontières. An initial estimate showed that 38,000 heads of cattle were stolen and 208 children were kidnapped.[557]
name: Uror massacre

description: Two Chinese cargo ships were attacked on a stretch of the Mekong River in the Golden Triangle area. All 13 crew members were killed and dumped in the river.[558] It is the deadliest assault on Chinese nationals abroad in modern times.[559]
name: Mekong River massacre

description: Partly as reaction for previous massacres, the Nuer White Army released a statement stating its intention to "wipe out the entire Murle tribe on the face of the earth as the only solution to guarantee long-term security of Nuer's cattle"[560] and massacred members of the Murle people.[561]
name: Pibor massacre

description: 17 Afghan civilians were killed by U.S. Army Soldier Robert Bales.[562] Some witnesses have indicated more than one person was involved.[563]
name: Kandahar massacre

description: Approximately 108 people were killed with knives in the Syrian town of Houla. Approximately 25 men, 49 children and 34 women were among the victims.[564]
name: Houla massacre

description: Egyptian security forces and army raided two camps of protesters in Cairo: one at al-Nahda Square and a larger one at Rabaa al-Adawiya Square. The two sites had been occupied by supporters of ousted President Mohamed Morsi. Reports of fatalities range from 600 to more than 800 civilians, while at least 3,994 were injured.
name: Rabaa massacre

description: During the breakout of the South Sudanese Civil War, Dinka SPLA soldiers rounded up and killed Nuer men from Nuer suburbs in the capital, Juba.[565]
name: Gudele massacre

description: During the South Sudanese Civil War, rebels massacred mostly non-Nuer civilians after taking control of Bentiu.[566]
name: 2014 Bentiu massacre

description: An ISIS massacre of Yazidi men.
name: Sinjar massacre

description: Seven gunmen affiliated with the Tehrik-i-Taliban (TTP) conducted a terrorist attack on the Army Public School killing more than 150 people, including 134 schoolchildren, ranging between eight and eighteen years of age.
name: 2014 Peshawar school massacre

description: A mass shooting perpetrated by Dylann Roof, a 21-year-old white supremacist, opened fire at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, killing 9.
name: Charleston church massacre

description: November 2015 Paris attacks. The single deadliest terrorist attack in French history. Multiple shooting and grenade attacks occurred on a Friday night; among the locations targeted were a music venue, sports stadium and several bar and restaurant terraces. 90 persons were killed during a siege at an Eagles of Death Metal concert inside the Bataclan. French president François Hollande evacuated from a football match between France and Germany at the Stade de France, slated venue for the UEFA Euro 2016 Final, after three separate suicide bombings over the course of about 40 minutes. ISIS claimed responsibility for the attacks and President Hollande named the Paris attacks an "act of war".[568]
name: Bataclan massacre

description: A mass shooting perpetrated by Omar Mateen, a 29-year-old U.S. citizen, opened fire in the Pulse Nightclub, a gay nightclub, killing 49, and injuring 50+. ISIS claimed responsibility for the attacks. It was the worst shooting massacre by a lone perpetrator in modern U.S. history, until the 2017 Las Vegas shooting.[569]
name: Orlando massacre
